nodes.bodyText:
Since Spring Boot has been updated to 2.3.4, this bug spring-projects/spring-boot#22566 has been fixed, and there should be no need for overriding Tomcat version anymore, so this could be removed:
ext['tomcat.version'] = '9.0.37' 
Would be good to verify that the too-many-contexts-created problem is indeed fixed now.
More: https://jira.niis.org/browse/XRDDEV-1204?focusedCommentId=14794&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14794
Also unless it was already done, effects of Spring Boot 2.3 upgrade should be tested. Some pointers from release log, may be relevant or not:

do we need to add validator starter dependency? https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.3-Release-Notes#validation-starter-no-longer-included-in-web-starters
are there any configuration properties that need to updated? Maybe run this: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.3-Release-Notes#configuration-properties

Maybe a separate ticket for these Spring Boot 2.3.x upgrade related things would be good?

Some discussion already in slack PMs. I understand a) proxy shadow jar and b) common-util + serverconf are  not needed at the same time strictly as dependencies, but exist due to secondary technical reasons:

shadow jar: parallel builds can fail without it
IntelliJ IDEA cannot handle just the shadow jar dependency by itself

Maybe consider adding some kind of comment about this? Otherwise future maintainers might not understand why this setup exists (and e.g. remove either "redundant" one).
Challenge is how to do this without lots of repeats, since similar structure is used in several other places. Don't know the answer, but maybe repeats is not horribly wrong after all.

nodes.bodyText: Is this comment change accidental? ("implementation time")
(although I am not 100% sure about the comment even before the change...does it say something useful)

I guess @Riippi asked about what happens if there's no changes to code, but a new vulnerability has been added to database.
I understand it works so that gradle clean build will - naturally - do the audit check, but a gradle build when there is an earlier tracked build, will not.
I think that the behavior feels pretty natural that way. Daily Jenkins builds will also fail if new vulnerabilities are added to database, since they do a clean build.

Ran into some issues with build. Not sure if related to this task, but mentioning it anyway. This might work like this already in current develop, maybe I will check tomorrow. For me this is reproducible.

clean proxy-ui-api module

~/p/n/x/g/X/s/proxy-ui-api (XRDDEV-1085 ⚡↩☡=) ../gradlew clean

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 2s
1 actionable task: 1 executed



build root project -> one proxy-ui-api test fails

~/p/n/x/g/X/src (XRDDEV-1085 ⚡↩☡=) ./gradlew build

> Task :proxy-ui-api:test

org.niis.xroad.restapi.openapi.ServiceDescriptionsApiControllerIntegrationTest > refreshServiceDescription FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError at ServiceDescriptionsApiControllerIntegrationTest.java:250


build root project again -> proxy-ui-api tests now all pass. This time messagelog test fails.

> Task :addons:messagelog:test

ee.ria.xroad.proxy.messagelog.MessageLogTest > logTimestampArchiveAndClean FAILED
    java.lang.RuntimeException at MessageLogTest.java:514

commit.message:
XRDDEV-1085: Downgrade Spring Boot back to 2.2.9

* Downgrade Spring Boot back to 2.2.9 due to intermittent test failures.
* Parameterize Mockito version
